channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SOLR-3625] Solr conf class loader does not find indirect jars - regression
item.description:
The SolrConf class loader does not find indirectly used jars from external lib directories. This is a regression. It worked as of July 2, 2012, when I posted the most recent OpenNLP patch (LUCENE-2899). Something has broken since then.

This regression is true in both 4.x and the trunk. Both worked on July 2, 2012.

I have a project (the OpenNLP plugin) which uses jars from three places:

  1. solr/contrib/opennlp/src
    • tokenizer and filter factories
  2. solr/contrib/opennlp/lib
    • OpenNLP project libraries
  3. lucene/analysis/opennlp/src
    • tokenizer and filter

SolrConf can only find the OpenNLP project jars when I add them to the solr.war libraries. It cannot find them from any of these directories: 

solr/example/solr/lib
solr/example/solr/collection1/lib
solr/contrib/opennlp/lib

Here are the relevant config file entries. From solrconfig.xml:

  <lib dir="../../../dist/" regex="apache-solr-opennlp-\d.*\.jar" />
  <lib dir="../../../contrib/opennlp/lib" regex=".*\.jar" />

(yes, it needs to be three dot-dot-slash, not two. See SOLR-3624.)
From schema.xml:

    <!-- OpenNLP all-in-one analyzer -->
    <fieldType name="text_opennlp" class="solr.TextField" positionIncrementGap="
100"
    >
      <analyzer>
        <tokenizer class="solr.OpenNLPTokenizerFactory"
          sentenceModel="opennlp/en-test-sent.bin"
          tokenizerModel="opennlp/en-test-tokenizer.bin"
        />
      </analyzer>
    </fieldType>

Here is the log. opennlp.tools.sentdetect.SentenceModel is a class in the OpenNLP jar.

INFO: Adding 'file:/Users/lancenorskog/Documents/open/solr/trunk/solr/dist/apache-solr-opennlp-5.0-SNAPSHOT.jar' to classloader

item.summary: Solr conf class loader does not find indirect jars - regression

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I take it back. This is not a regression. I just now retested with the version of 4.x I used earlier, and it does not work either.

Indirect jars are not found by SolrConf in external library directories, only when packed into the war.

Indirect jars are not found by SolrConf in external library directories, only when packed into the war.

Well, that blanket statement can't be true – you can clearly see using the example that the velocity libs are loaded because /browse works fine.

Lance: I'm having trouble getting the latest patch in LUCENE-2899 to work, but i have a theory as to what's going on here...

Here is the log. opennlp.tools.sentdetect.SentenceModel is a class in the OpenNLP jar.

if by "the OpenNLP jar" you mean "one of the jars in ../../../contrib/opennlp/lib" then i think what you are seeing here is a natural effect of the way hierarcical ClassLoaders work.

Each <lib /> directive is processed in sequence, and used to build a ClassLoader that wraps the existing classloader (hence the name of the method "replaceClassLoader") – so the order of the <lib /> directives can matter depending on what dependencies exist between various jars (sometimes it doesn't matter, there are nuances there that i have trouble remembering)

I suspect what you had working before was...

  <lib dir="../../../contrib/opennlp/lib" regex=".*\.jar" />
  <lib dir="../../../dist/" regex="apache-solr-opennlp-\d.*\.jar" />

...where a classloader for the the "lower level" libraries was created first, and then the solr specific libraries were used to create a high level clasloader that wraped it.

can you try that with an uptodate version of your LUCENE-2899 patch and see if it addressess the root issue?

if so, then i think we just need to do a better job of documenting on the wiki that the order is significant
moving all 4.0 issues not touched in a month to 4.1

Lacking any other feedback, i'm assuming my assessment was correct, and i've added more comments to the example solrconfig.xml about order of <lib/> directives being significant – i also updated the existing examples to follow this advice.

Committed revision 1384529.
Committed revision 1384533. - 4x

I did not find a problem with the order of <lib> directives inside solrconfig.xml. All <lib> directives in solrconfig.xml seem to have one classloader. The problem happens when a Lucene jar refers to a third-party jar and Solr code outside the war tries to load the factory.

I have added a detailed explanation of the problem to SOLR-3760

[branch_4x commit] Chris M. Hostetter
http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1384533

SOLR-3625: better info in example conigs about <lib/> and how order might matter (merge r1384529)
